answers.name: Answer 5
answers.text:
North Sea shrimp salad.
Mix North sea shrimps with mayo, diced hard boiled eggs, salt, pepper. Parsley is optional, forget the tomatoes.
 
Served in a Belgian Pistolet roll. Unbeatable.
 
Runner up:
 
Americain preparé: raw beef mixed with egg yolk, mayo, Worcester sauce, tabasco. Top with diced onions, capers or gurkins. A Belgian classic.
Honourable mention:
 
Piadina with mortadella, Stracciatella and pistacchio.

answers.name: Answer 8
answers.text:
Ham, cheese and egg sandwich
 
The toast is fried on the outside and soft on the inside, with ham and cheese
 
It's delicious, try it if you like it~
Ingredients:
 
2 slices of toast
 
4 eggs
 
3 slices of cheese
 
Some tomato sauce
 
Some black pepper and salt
Method:
 
1. Beat the eggs and mix well with salt and black pepper
 
2. Put butter in the pan, turn on low heat, pour half of the egg liquid and put the toast
 
3. Wait for the egg liquid to solidify, turn it over and fold it four times
 
4. Put a slice of cheese and ham on it, and then put half of the cheese slice on it
 
Squeeze tomato sauce on it, fold the toast in half

answers.name: Answer 10
answers.text:
My favourite sandwich ingredient is mature cheddar cheese.
 
None of these ultra processed sliced cheeses. Nor a mild or rubbery cheese. But a good honest mature cheddar - offering firmness and tanginess. Personal favourite cheddar cheeses are from the UK’s West Country - matured for at least 18 months.
 
As for the bread, my preference is home baked. I have a baking machine to speed up this process. A crusty, well risen white loaf is a vehicle for the flavoursome cheese. Or it a loaf of a wholemeal or white mix - offering flavour and texture.
 
The spread must be butter and the entire sandwich seasone

My favourite sandwich ingredient is mature cheddar cheese.
 
None of these ultra processed sliced cheeses. Nor a mild or rubbery cheese. But a good honest mature cheddar - offering firmness and tanginess. Personal favourite cheddar cheeses are from the UK’s West Country - matured for at least 18 months.
 
As for the bread, my preference is home baked. I have a baking machine to speed up this process. A crusty, well risen white loaf is a vehicle for the flavoursome cheese. Or it a loaf of a wholemeal or white mix - offering flavour and texture.
 
The spread must be butter and the entire sandwich seasoned with black pepper fresh from the mill.
 
Non-guilty pleasure: a parmesan cheese sandwich. Not grated parmesan, but thick calorific slides of Parmigiano.
 
Writing this Quora answer has left me famished.

answers.text:
First, ham is my go-to ingredient. Its rich flavor and moderate saltiness make every bite full of satisfaction. At the same time, the texture of ham is also very good. It is chewy but not too hard, which fits perfectly into the sandwich.
Next is Swiss cheese. Its milky flavor and smooth taste form a wonderful contrast when combined with ham. Swiss cheese becomes more fragrant after heating, especially in toasted sandwiches, and the stringy effect of cheese is mouth-watering.
Finally, I like to add fresh vegetables to the sandwich, especially lettuce and tomatoes. The crispness of lettuce and the
Continue Reading
First, ham is my go-to ingredient. Its rich flavor and moderate saltiness make every bite full of satisfaction. At the same time, the texture of ham is also very good. It is chewy but not too hard, which fits perfectly into the sandwich.
Next is Swiss cheese. Its milky flavor and smooth taste form a wonderful contrast when combined with ham. Swiss cheese becomes more fragrant after heating, especially in toasted sandwiches, and the stringy effect of cheese is mouth-watering.
Finally, I like to add fresh vegetables to the sandwich, especially lettuce and tomatoes. The crispness of lettuce and the juiciness of tomatoes add a fresh taste to the whole sandwich, making the taste more layered. These vegetables also make the sandwich look more tempting and improve the nutritional value.

answers.name: Answer 12
answers.text:
Peppered Pastrami.
I don’t mean the MEGA pastrami sandwiches I see on American youtube videos like this
Years and years ago near the 6th form college I went to, there was a small Italian bistro. They did £1.20 pastrami sandwiches, which was actually quite expensive in the 1990s. They’d stick it in hot water to heat it up a little and it would be put in a bread roll.
 
The 10 minute breaks between lectures meant there was enough time to go out cross the road and get a sandwich.
 
I never tasted anything that tasted quite like these sandwiches 25 years later :/

-
 
🔺Taro and pork floss sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, taro , purple potato flour, milk, seaweed meat floss
 
[Method] Steam the taro, add appropriate amount of purple potato flour, milk, sugar substitute, and beat into taro paste. Spread thick taro paste on both slices of toast, spread seaweed meat floss on one slice and press it, cover with another slice of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Mango and crab stick sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, mango, crab stick, tomato, lettuce, salad dressing
 
[Method] Tear crab stick into strips, slice mango, put lettuce, mango slices, crab stick, salad dressing on toast in order , tomato slices, cover with another piece of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Cheese and corn sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, corn, ham, meat floss, cheese slices
 
[Method] Squeeze the cooked corn kernels and ham cubes with salad dressing and mix well. Spread meat floss, cheese slices, and corn and ham salad on the toast in turn, cover with another piece of toast and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Mango yogurt sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, mango, solid yogurt
 
[Method] Pour the yogurt into gauze and suspend it in the air, refrigerate Filter out the whey overnight, take out the solid yogurt and stir it until smooth, spread a thick layer of yogurt on both slices of toast, put half a mango pulp on it, cover it with another slice of toast, and wrap it with plastic wrap
 
-
 
🔺Kimchi beef sandwich
 
[Ingredients] Toast, beef, kimchi, eggs, cheese slices, seaweed shreds
 
[Method] Fry a poached egg, fry the beef slices with seasoning, put the poached egg, seaweed shreds, cheese slices, beef slices, kimchi on the toast in order, cover it with another slice of toast and wrap it with plastic wrap

: Some people may not like it. However I do love it not only because it tastes good, but it can also help moisten the sandwich. From my experience, if you don’t spread mayo on your sandwich, it can be very dry for you to swallow your sandwich.
Caramelised Onion
: It adds an amazing sweetness to your sandwich. Sweat your onions (I prefer red onions personally) with some oil, and then add your balsamic vinegar & sugar, let the it reduce until you end up with a soft caramelised onions.
Bacon
: Just because it’s good haha.
Gherkin
: Adds a slight sourness, and when eaten together with other ingredients in the sandwich, it complements the whole thing very well.
Smoke
: When I’m in the mood for it, I like to grill my sandwich. The smokiness from the grill just adds another layer of flavour. I said this because I believe the term “Flavour” is the quality of something that can trigger your 5 senses (taste, smell, hear, sight, feel/touch).

answers.text:
Cheese (Cheddar or Gouda)
A classic, creamy,
and melty cheese always elevates a sandwich. Cheddar has a sharp flavor, while Gouda is smooth and slightly smoky. Both pair wonderfully with meats or veggies.
Roast Beef
Savory, tender roast beef adds a rich and hearty flavor. It’s perfect with mustard, horseradish, or even a bit of cheese.
A great option for a filling, satisfying sandwich.
Tomatoes
Fresh, juicy tomatoes bring a burst of sweetness and juiciness to any sandwich. They're great for balancing out richer ingredients like bacon or cheese.

Crispy, salty bacon adds crunch and a smoky flavor t
Continue Reading
Cheese (Cheddar or Gouda)
A classic, creamy,
and melty cheese always elevates a sandwich. Cheddar has a sharp flavor, while Gouda is smooth and slightly smoky. Both pair wonderfully with meats or veggies.
Roast Beef
Savory, tender roast beef adds a rich and hearty flavor. It’s perfect with mustard, horseradish, or even a bit of cheese.
A great option for a filling, satisfying sandwich.
Tomatoes
Fresh, juicy tomatoes bring a burst of sweetness and juiciness to any sandwich. They're great for balancing out richer ingredients like bacon or cheese.
Bacon
Crispy, salty bacon adds crunch and a smoky flavor that can make any sandwich feel extra special. It pairs well with just about anything—avocado, eggs, or even in a classic BLT.
Lettuce (Arugula or Romaine)
Fresh, crunchy greens like arugula or romaine provide a
nice contrast to the other ingredients. Arugula, in particular, has a peppery kick that adds a little zing.
Chicken (Grilled or Rotisserie)
Lean and versatile, grilled or rotisserie chicken is a great option for a lighter sandwich. It pairs well with anything
from pesto and mozzarella to classic mayo or avocado.
A fried egg adds a richness and a bit of creaminess to a sandwich. The runny yolk is especially delicious if paired with bacon or avocado.

Ham croissant sandwich with latte
 
Croissant | Plant ham slices | Egg | Lettuce | Tomato
 
(or other ingredients you like)
 
1. Bake the croissant at 180 degrees for about 6 minutes, cut and set aside
 
2. Add some water to two eggs and stir well, add a little oil to the pan, and keep pushing it to the middle to solidify it into a scrambled egg
 
3. Fry a few slices of ham, cut other ingredients, and assemble the sandwich as you like
With simple assembly, you can get a croissant sandwich comparable to that of a fast food restaurant! Today, both sandwiches use the fruit smoked plant ham slices from Zhouqiling

If we have leftover steak, I buy chipotle peppers in adobo sauce, and take a spoon of adobo sauce and add it to mayonnaise until it has a good flavor but not too spicy. The sandwich is chipotle mayo, thin cut steak, and sharp cheddar cheese. Growing up, mom made tuna and mayo. Her friends put pickle relish in tuna which I found to be as disgusting as candied yams. Later in life, I make tuna with hard boiled eggs, mayo and a little mustard…like deviled egg tuna salad. Finally, which comes only once a year…turkey and mayo on homemade white bread.

i have to agree with Dan Hunter, bread really makes the sandwich. growing up in the ’70s and ’80s in the south (U.S.) eating commercial white bread, i didn’t really understand that, but now i do.
 
i remember the first couple of times traveling to spain and seeing sandwiches everywhere, a thin baguette with just a tiny bit of ham and cheese and thinking what nerve they had calling that a sandwich and charging that kind of price.
 
because i was thinking in the subway/blimpie frame of mind — what you put on the bread is what you’re paying for and the spanish sandwiches looked pretty skimpy on the fillings.
 
it didn’t take me long to realize the bread was a key element of the sandwich, versus being simply a carrier for the filling. it was eye-opening.
 
good bread is really the most essential part of a sandwich, and it depends on the sandwich, as well! for example, sometimes even the lowly loaf of white bread is just the right thing for a certain type of sandwich. just as a hearty slice of rye is perfect for others.

When it comes to creating the perfect sandwich, the choice of ingredients can elevate a simple meal into a culinary delight. While many might argue over the merits of various toppings and spreads, I can confidently assert that avocado reigns supreme as my favorite sandwich ingredient.
 
First and foremost, the texture of avocado is nothing short of magical. Its creamy, buttery consistency adds a luxurious mouthfeel that enhances the overall bite of any sandwich. Whether it’s slathered on as a spread, sliced and layered, or mashed into a flavorful mixture, avocado seamlessly integrates with other ingredients while still maintaining its unique identity.
 
Flavor-wise, avocado boasts a mild earthiness that serves as an excellent backdrop for a myriad of flavor profiles. It pairs beautifully with zesty ingredients like tomatoes, onions, and pickles, perfectly balancing their acidity with its rich creaminess. Furthermore, it complements savory proteins such as turkey, chicken, or even bacon, enhancing the overall savory experience without overpowering other flavors. A sprinkle of salt and a dash of lime can take this ingredient to a whole new level, providing a fresh burst of taste that energizes the palate.
 
One of the most appealing aspects of avocado is its versatility. It fits perfectly into various sandwich styles—be it a classic club, a refreshing veggie pack, or even a bold and spicy sriracha chicken creation. Its adaptability knows no bounds, allowing it to be featured in both cold and hot sandwiches with equal success. Additionally, for those who prioritize health, avocados are loaded with beneficial nutrients like healthy fats, fiber, and vitamins, making them not just a delicious choice, but a nutritious one too.
 
While some might debate the issue of ripeness or the daunting task of slicing the perfect avocado, the rewards far outweigh the risks. A perfectly ripe avocado can transform an ordinary sandwich into something truly special.
 
In conclusion, if you’re seeking to elevate your sandwich game, look no further than the humble avocado. With its creamy texture, versatile flavor, and health benefits, it rightfully claims the top spot as my favorite sandwich ingredient. Whether you’re crafting a casual lunch or impressing guests at a gathering, incorporating avocado will undoubtedly impress and satisfy—proving that sometimes, simplicity is key to perfection.

Sandwiches are a versatile and universally loved food, and their magic lies in the endless combinations of ingredients that can be used. While everyone has their preferences, here are some popular sandwich ingredients that stand out as favorites:
Cheese
Whether it’s cheddar, mozzarella, or Swiss, cheese is often a go-to ingredient. It adds a creamy texture and a delightful tanginess that complements almost any filling. Melted cheese in a grilled sandwich? Pure perfection!
Avocado
For a creamy, healthy twist, avocado is a favorite. Its mild flavor pairs well with other ingredients, and it’s a great option for those looking for a nutritious addition.
Chicken or Turkey
Grilled chicken, roasted turkey, or deli-style slices are perfect for a protein-packed sandwich. Their flavor pairs well with fresh veggies and sauces.
Tomatoes and Lettuce
These two staples bring freshness and crunch. A slice of juicy tomato and crisp lettuce balance out richer ingredients like meats and cheeses.
Eggs

The Argentine sandwich, known as "sandwich de milanesa," is a beloved staple in Argentine cuisine, adored for its simplicity and deliciousness.
The sandwich de milanesa typically features a breaded and fried beef or chicken fillet, known as milanesa, which is similar to the Italian cotoletta. The meat is usually pounded thin, coated in egg and breadcrumbs, and then fried until golden and crispy.
 
The key components of a sandwich de milanesa are the milanesa itself, bread (often a crusty roll or baguette), and various toppings. Common additions include lettuce, tomato, avocado, and mayonnaise. Some people also like to add cheese or a squeeze of lime for extra flavor.
 
This sandwich is more than just food; it represents 
comfort and home for many Argentines
. It's commonly found in eateries known as "cafés" or sandwich shops throughout the country.

Hey there! Sandwiches are one of the best things ever, right? They’re quick, easy, and you can pack them with all kinds of delicious and nutritious ingredients. But what’s the 
best
 sandwich ingredient? Well, that depends on what you’re looking for—flavor, health, or just pure yumminess. Instead of writing about my favorite ingredients, I shared detailed information about sandwiches so you can decide what you want to include in your own creation. Let’s dive into some top picks for building the ultimate sandwich!
1. The Protein Powerhouse
 
Every great sandwich needs a good protein. Protein keeps you full and helps build and repair your muscles. Here are some all-star options:
Grilled Chicken or Turkey:
 Lean and flavorful, these options are perfect for a light, healthy sandwich. Add some mustard or avocado for extra zing!
Eggs:
 Hard-boiled or scrambled, eggs are a classic. They’re rich in protein and vitamins, and they go well with almost anything.
Plant-Based Proteins:
 For veggie lovers, try hummus, tempeh, or even smashed chickpeas. These options are not just healthy but also super satisfying.
2. The Creamy Spread
 
No sandwich is complete without a spread to tie everything together. Choose something that adds flavor without piling on empty calories:
Avocado:
 Creamy, delicious, and full of healthy fats. It’s a great substitute for butter or mayo. Mash it up with a little salt and pepper for a spread you’ll love.
Hummus:
 A fantastic plant-based option that’s rich in protein and fiber. It comes in different flavors, so you can mix things up—roasted red pepper, garlic, or plain.
Greek Yogurt Spread:
 Mix plain Greek yogurt with herbs and spices for a tangy, creamy spread. It’s lower in fat than mayo and tastes amazing.
3. The Crunch Factor
 
You can’t skip the crunch! It’s the texture that makes every bite exciting. Here are some ideas to keep things interesting:
Leafy Greens:
 Romaine lettuce, spinach, or arugula adds freshness and a satisfying crunch. Plus, they’re packed with vitamins and antioxidants.
Thinly Sliced Veggies:
 Cucumber, bell peppers, and carrots are perfect for adding crunch and color. Bonus: they’re super hydrating and low in calories.
Pickles:
 For a tangy twist, add pickles or banana peppers. They give your sandwich a zesty kick!
4. The Cheesy Touch
 
If you’re a cheese lover, this is your time to shine. A little cheese goes a long way to add creaminess and flavor:
Sliced Cheddar or Swiss:
 Classic choices that melt beautifully if you’re making a toasted sandwich.
Feta or Goat Cheese:
 These crumbly cheeses add a tangy, gourmet vibe to your sandwich.
Vegan Cheese:
 There are great plant-based cheese options out there if you’re avoiding dairy.
5. The Secret Ingredient
 
Every sandwich needs that one thing that takes it to the next level. Here are some game-changers:
Pesto:
 Spread a thin layer of pesto for a burst of herby flavor. It’s especially great with chicken or roasted veggies.
Sriracha or Hot Sauce:
 Add a little heat to wake up your taste buds. Just a drizzle will do!
Fruits:
 Yes, fruits! Sliced apples, pears, or even dried cranberries can add a sweet contrast to savory ingredients.
How to Build the Perfect Sandwich
 
Now that you’ve got all these amazing ingredients to choose from, here’s how to put it all together:
Start with a base: whole-grain bread, a wrap, or even a lettuce leaf for a low-carb option.
Add your protein: pick your favorite meat, eggs, or plant-based protein.
Layer on the veggies: the more color, the better!
Spread it out: choose a healthy spread like hummus or avocado.
Finish strong: sprinkle on cheese, nuts, or that secret ingredient to make it truly yours.
The Bottom Line
 
The best sandwich ingredient is the one that makes you excited to eat your meal! Whether you’re in the mood for creamy avocado, crunchy veggies, or flavorful pesto, there are so many ways to create a healthy, delicious sandwich that’s totally your style.
 
So go ahead, get creative, and build a sandwich that’s not just a meal—it’s an experience. Enjoy! 😊

When considering what colors look good with pink, it’s crucial to understand the versatility of this color. Pink can range from soft pastels to bright hues, and it pairs well with a variety of other colors, depending on the desired aesthetic. Here are some effective combinations:
 
1. Pink and White
 
Pink pairs beautifully with white, creating a fresh, bright look. This combination works particularly well in casual settings, such as summer outfits or home decor, where light pink can be paired with white furniture or decor to create a clean look.
 
2. Pink and Gray
 
Gray is a great neutral backdrop for pink. The softness of pink with gray creates a sophisticated and modern look that’s perfect for clothing and interior design. Light pink can soften the starkness of gray tones, making them more appealing.
 
3. Pink and Black
 
For a bold statement, pairing pink with black can create a striking contrast. This combination is common in the fashion world, where bright pink outfits are paired with black accessories or bottoms, adding an edgy touch to the overall outfit.
 
4. Pink and Blue
 
Blue tones, especially softer shades like pale blue or denim blue, pair well with pink. This combination creates a tranquil vibe and works well both in fashion (like a pale pink shirt with blue jeans) and in home decor (like light pink walls with navy furniture).
 
5. Pink and Green
 
Due to their opposite positions on the color wheel, greens complement pink beautifully. This pairing ranges from soft mint greens paired with pale pinks to darker emerald greens paired with bolder pinks for a vibrant look.
 
6. Pink and Brown
 
Brown tones add warmth when paired with pink, creating an earthy yet stylish hue. Dull or muted pinks work well with rich browns, both in clothing choices and interior spaces.
 
7. Pink and Yellow
 
Bright yellow adds a cheerful feel when paired with pink, perfect for playful designs or summer outfits. This lively combination is perfect for creating a vibrant space or a fun fashion statement.
 
In summary, pink looks great with white, gray, black, blue, green, brown, and yellow, creating a variety of styles from soft and elegant to bold statements.

answers.text:
One of the favorite sandwich ingredients for many is 
avocado
. It adds a creamy texture and a rich, buttery flavor, while also providing healthy fats, vitamins, and minerals.
Avocado pairs well with various ingredients, from turkey and bacon to vegetables and hummus, making it a versatile choice for elevating any sandwich!

answers.name: Answer 163
answers.text: I'd say my favorite sandwich ingredient is a perfectly ripe avocado creamy, nutritious, and it adds a great texture to any sandwich
